candidates.title: Create winit canvas under WebAssembly

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Windowing
labels.description: Platform-agnostic interface layer to run your app in

labels.name: O-Web
labels.description: Specific to web (WASM) builds

candidates.body:
With this change `wasm32` build will actually create "window" canvas in browser and process input events on it.

![Zrzut ekranu z 2020-09-17 22-11-53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/147687/93525223-fd829d80-f935-11ea-9a82-0842000c3a7f.png)

candidates.title: Implement WASM support for bevy_winit

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Windowing
labels.description: Platform-agnostic interface layer to run your app in

labels.name: O-Web
labels.description: Specific to web (WASM) builds

candidates.body:
This modifies the rest of default plugins to build for `wasm32` and twists `bevy_winit` to run.

The main problem is that winit Window is not Send + Sync, but since our WASM runtime is single threaded,
we can safely fake it.

![Zrzut ekranu z 2020-09-16 22-02-02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/147687/93387340-59cbbb80-f869-11ea-8e33-a8ecf5b8e2ec.png)

Also, replaced wasm_timer::Instant with instant::Instant as it is used by winit WASM implementation, so the code won't duplicate.

To build the example use:
```sh
cargo build --example winit_wasm --target wasm32-unknown-unknown --no-default-features --features bevy_winit
```
and modify `index.html` to run it.

candidates.title: Implement single threaded task scheduler for WebAssembly

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: O-Web
labels.description: Specific to web (WASM) builds

candidates.body:
This implements a single threaded "TaskPool" and systems scheduler for use with WebAssembly target.

I see it as a temporary solution, until Rust wasm story gets better support for wasm threads (see #88). This is why I kept my change minimal, without any major refactoring. It is ugly, but it works.

Provided examples demonstrate how to build and run `wasm32` target. See examples/README.md.

Bevy is now able to run "headless" in browser.
![Zrzut ekranu z 2020-09-15 22-53-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/147687/93264855-07769600-f7a8-11ea-9160-b213c9c91892.png)

Together with #209 it should be enough (+/- fixes) to run Bevy app in browser.

candidates.title: Make "render" feature optional

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: A-Build-System
labels.description: Related to build systems or continuous integration

candidates.body:
This PR makes the whole render pipeline optional.

I made this as a pre-requisite to build Bevy for WASM, but it is also useful in other contexts, i.e. headless.

candidates.title: Update multitask dependency to async-executor

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Build-System
labels.description: Related to build systems or continuous integration

candidates.body:
Switch from the deprecated `multitask` crate to `async-executor`
* async-executor 0.2 appears to be essentially multitask 0.3, written by the same person with mostly the same code
    * async-executor 0.1 actually used multitask 0.2 as a dependency
* use block_on in futures_lite instead of pollster because futures_lite is already in the dependency list of async-executor

Unfortunately this does increase the number of crates involved, but I think in practice because the crates are small and focused it's not so bad. I'm going to use clean build time as an extremely crude indicator for how "big" of a dependency it is.
* Before: 13 crates, 1.3s clean build time
* After: 22 crates, 1.8s clean build time
* Rayon: 30 crates, 5.54 clean build time

Also for reference:
* tokio: 16.3s
* async-std: 8.3s
* smol: 3.1s

BTW, async-std and smol use async-executor 0.1 (and therefore multitask 0.2).

Additionally the dependencies added here would enable us to also adopt async-lock, async-barrier, async-mutex, async-rwlock, and async-semaphore with no additional dependencies if they were needed. There are some other components in smol that we or downstream users of bevy could adopt if they need it.

*** I suggest NOT integrating this CL until what we have gets some more usage and seems stable.

candidates.title: Parallel queries

labels.name: C-Feature

labels.description: Entities, components, systems, and events

candidates.body:
~~Implements IntoParallelIterator for QueryBorrow for rayon integration. I didn't end up using hecs built in BatchedIter, since it doesn't really mesh well with rayon.~~

Implements a ParallelIterator trait on top of bevy_task, which operates on batches. Then implements ParallelIterator for bevy_ecs::query's BatchedIterator.

~~*Still needs to be tested.*~~ Example included

candidates.title: Added gamepad support using Gilrs

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Input
labels.description: Player input via keyboard, mouse, gamepad, and more

candidates.body:
Implements #94 
Partially implements/uses a temporary implementation for #59 

I have added crate `bevy_gilrs` which contains the system to:
* Generate connect/disconnect event using resource `Event<GamepadEvent>`
* Store gamepad's buttons state using resource `Input<GamepadButton>`
* Store gamepad's axes state using resource `Axis<GamepadAxis>`

Added a temporary implementation of `Axis<T>` as there are other PRs open for that. (I will rebase this PR after they are merged or should I implement them here?)

Added `Gamepad`, `GamepadButton`, `GamepadAxis`, `GamepadEvent`, `GamepadEventType`, `ButtonCode` and `AxisCode` to crate `bevy_input`. These structs are exposed to the user. These structs are modified/generated using the systems inside `bevy_gilrs`.

Suggestions Needed:
* Regarding names of these structs.
* `gilrs::Gilrs` struct implements `!Send`, so I wrapped it inside an `Arc<Mutex<T>>` and implements Send unsafely. Are there any other approach to add `gilrs::Gilrs` as a `Resource`?

Check the example `examples/input/gamepad_input.rs` for usage.

Note: Need more polish before merge(comments), until then, review it.
